questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:
  • ➤ PBG synthase Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ PBG synthase
  • ➤ Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 306-307

questions.text: A researcher is studying the impact of environmental factors on gene expression in a group of identical twins who have developed different traits despite having the same DNA sequence. The study focuses on how certain chemical modifications can regulate gene activity without altering the underlying genetic code. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for altering gene expression through methylation and acetylation without changing the gene sequence?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Epigenetics is the study of heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve changes to the underlying DNA sequence. This involves mechanisms like DNA methylation, which adds a methyl group to DNA, usually at cytosine residues in CpG islands, leading to gene silencing, and histone acetylation, which loosens the chromatin structure, allowing transcription factors access to the DNA, thus promoting gene expression. These modifications can turn genes on or off without altering the DNA sequence itself and can be influenced by environmental factors, making epigenetics a key area in understanding gene regulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Genetic mutation: Genetic mutations involve permanent changes in the DNA sequence, such as point mutations, deletions, or insertions, which can affect gene function. Unlike epigenetics, mutations directly alter the genetic code and are not reversible or influenced by methylation and acetylation.
  • • A. Genetic mutation:
  • • C. DNA replication errors: Errors during DNA replication can lead to changes in the DNA sequence, such as mismatched bases or strand slippage, potentially resulting in mutations. These errors directly change the DNA sequence and do not involve the reversible regulatory mechanisms seen in epigenetics.
  • • C. DNA replication errors:
  • • D. Chromosomal translocation: Chromosomal translocation involves the rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes, which can disrupt gene function or create new gene fusions. This process affects the physical structure of chromosomes rather than altering gene expression through methylation or acetylation.
  • • D. Chromosomal translocation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epigenetics refers to heritable changes in gene expression that occur without altering the DNA sequence, primarily through mechanisms such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation. These modifications influence how genes are activated or silenced, making epigenetics a critical component in gene regulation, development, and the response to environmental factors. Understanding these processes helps explain why identical genetic codes can lead to different phenotypic outcomes.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones? (INICET MAY 2023)

questions.explanation:

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency . Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.
  • ➤ X-linked
  • ➤ Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition: (INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairments and early childhood death.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: D. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase. It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.
  • • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.
  • • Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:
  • • Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.
  • • Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.
  • • Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the Respiratory Quotient (RQ) of a person consuming a pure carbohydrate diet? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Respiratory Quotient (RQ) is the ratio of CO2 produced to O2 consumed. On a pure carbohydrate diet, carbohydrates are completely oxidized to CO2 and water, leading to an RQ of 1. This is because the amount of CO2 produced is equal to the amount of O2 consumed.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • A. 0.7 : This RQ value is typical of a diet high in fats, which require more oxygen for oxidation compared to the carbon they yield as CO2. C. 1.2 and D. 1.5 : These values are not typical RQs for any standard macronutrient-based diet and could only be seen in pathological conditions or with substrates not typically found in a normal diet.
  • • A. 0.7 : This RQ value is typical of a diet high in fats, which require more oxygen for oxidation compared to the carbon they yield as CO2.
  • • A. 0.7
  • • C. 1.2 and D. 1.5 : These values are not typical RQs for any standard macronutrient-based diet and could only be seen in pathological conditions or with substrates not typically found in a normal diet.
  • • C. 1.2
  • • D. 1.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Respiratory Quotient (RQ) for a pure carbohydrate diet is 1, reflecting the equal molar consumption of O2 and production of CO2, which is characteristic of carbohydrate metabolism.

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase:
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 240, 245
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 240, 245

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UV absorption occur due to conjugated double bonds in the ring. So, to increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by any aromatic amino acids such as Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Out of these, tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine due to presence of two rings in its side chain compared to only one in other two amino acids.
  • ➤ Out of these, tryptophan
  • ➤ All other amino acid given here do not absorb UV light due to lack of conjugated double bonds.
  • ➤ Guanine is nitrogenous base not amino acid. It absorbs at 260nm.
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Absorbance of compounds:
  • ➤ Absorbance of compounds:
  • ➤ Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids) Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases) NADH/NADPH - 340 nm Porphyrins - 400 nm ( Soret band).
  • ➤ Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids)
  • ➤ Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases)
  • ➤ NADH/NADPH - 340 nm
  • ➤ Porphyrins - 400 nm ( Soret band).
  • ➤ Soret

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Substrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: What is the primary precursor in the synthesis of steroid hormones? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pregnenolone serves as the foundational precursor in the synthesis of all steroid hormones. It is synthesized directly from cholesterol in the mitochondria of steroid-producing cells, such as those in the adrenal cortex and gonads. This transformation involves the cleavage of the cholesterol side chain, catalyzed by the enzyme cytochrome P450scc, making pregnenolone the first steroid formed in the steroidogenesis pathway. From pregnenolone, further enzymatic reactions lead to the production of various steroid hormones including glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and sex steroids.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • a. Cortisone: While a steroid hormone, cortisone is not a precursor but rather a downstream product in the steroidogenesis pathway. b. 7-Dihydrocholesterol: This compound is primarily involved in the synthesis of vitamin D3, not directly in the synthesis of steroid hormones. c. 7-Hydroxycholesterol: Like 7-dihydrocholesterol, this is not a direct precursor in the synthesis of steroid hormones.
  • • a. Cortisone: While a steroid hormone, cortisone is not a precursor but rather a downstream product in the steroidogenesis pathway.
  • • a. Cortisone:
  • • b. 7-Dihydrocholesterol: This compound is primarily involved in the synthesis of vitamin D3, not directly in the synthesis of steroid hormones.
  • • b. 7-Dihydrocholesterol:
  • • c. 7-Hydroxycholesterol: Like 7-dihydrocholesterol, this is not a direct precursor in the synthesis of steroid hormones.
  • • c. 7-Hydroxycholesterol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pregnenolone is the initial steroid synthesized from cholesterol and serves as the precursor for all other steroid hormones.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:
  • • The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:
  • • Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.
  • • Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.
  • • Source of NADPH:
  • • Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.
  • • Source of ribose 5 phosphate:
  • • Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.
  • • Source of acetyl CoA:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.
  • • Option D. Utilizes ribose:
  • • The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:
  • • The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:
  • • 3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.
  • ➤ Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • ➤ This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry's disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maltese cross casts in urinalysis are indicative of Fabry's disease due to the presence of glycolipid-laden renal tubular cells. These casts show a characteristic birefringent pattern under polarized light.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tests used for olfaction are as follows:
  • ➤ Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT) , is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.
  • ➤ Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  • ➤ Smell diskettes
  • ➤ University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  • ➤ University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
  • ➤ The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT) , is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  • ➤ Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT)
  • ➤ The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.
  • ➤ The Sniffin' Sticks
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with fatigue, pale skin, and shortness of breath. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia with a high ferritin level, low transferrin saturation, and a characteristic ringed sideroblast on bone marrow biopsy. The patient’s medical history includes chronic alcohol use and previous tuberculosis treated with isoniazid. Which treatment is commonly used for managing his type of anemia?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is commonly used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia, particularly when it is due to pyridoxine-dependent enzyme deficiencies. This condition often arises from disruptions in heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of iron within the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors, forming ringed sideroblasts. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in heme synthesis, enhancing the production of heme and reducing mitochondrial iron accumulation. This treatment is particularly effective in cases related to genetic disorders or acquired forms due to alcohol, isoniazid, or other drugs.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Folic Acid: Folic acid is used to treat megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency but is not effective in managing sideroblastic anemia, as it does not address the underlying problem of disrupted heme synthesis or iron accumulation in the mitochondria.
  • • A. Folic Acid:
  • • C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin stimulates red blood cell production and is used in anemia of chronic kidney disease and other forms of anemia due to low erythropoiesis, but it does not directly address the mitochondrial iron trapping seen in sideroblastic anemia.
  • • C. Erythropoietin:
  • • D. Iron Chelation Therapy: While iron chelation therapy is used in conditions with iron overload, it is not the primary treatment for sideroblastic anemia itself. Chelation helps manage iron toxicity rather than correcting the underlying defect in heme synthesis.
  • • D. Iron Chelation Therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is an effective treatment for sideroblastic anemia due to its role in heme synthesis. It aids in reducing iron accumulation in mitochondria and can improve hematologic outcomes, especially in cases related to pyridoxine-dependent enzyme deficiencies or acquired causes such as alcoholism and certain medications.

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is: ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.
  • • Option A. Oesophagus:
  • • Option B . Aorta : The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.
  • • Option B
  • • Aorta
  • • Option D . Sympathetic Chain : The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.
  • • Option D
  • • Sympathetic Chain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)
  • ➤ The diaphragm has three anatomic openings:
  • ➤ The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen. Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus. Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.
  • ➤ The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • ➤ Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • ➤ Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.
  • ➤ Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : ( INICET Nov 2023)

  • • Explanation
  • • All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Chickenpox : Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.
  • • Option A. Chickenpox
  • • Option B. Rubella : Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.
  • • Option B. Rubella
  • • Option C. CMV : The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.
  • • Option C. CMV
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection
  • • T oxoplasmosis O ther (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus) R ubella C ytomegalovirus (CMV) H erpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
  • • T oxoplasmosis
  • • T
  • • O ther (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • • O
  • • R ubella
  • • R
  • • C ytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • • C
  • • H erpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
  • • H
  • • Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient diagnosed with Wilson's disease presents with symptoms of hepatomegaly, neurological disturbances, and a distinctive golden-brown ring around the cornea. Laboratory tests confirm decreased serum ceruloplasmin and elevated liver copper content. Given the abnormal copper metabolism in Wilson's disease, which substance is typically found to be decreased in the patient's urine?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In Wilson's disease, 3-methylhistidine levels are typically decreased in the urine. Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation affecting copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues. This copper buildup disrupts normal metabolic processes, including the excretion of certain amino acids such as 3-methylhistidine. The reduced excretion of 3-methylhistidine in urine is associated with the overall disturbance in protein metabolism due to copper toxicity in the liver, affecting the breakdown and release of this compound into the urine.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Urea: Urea is a major end product of protein metabolism and is typically excreted normally or increased in urine in liver dysfunctions due to protein catabolism. It is not specifically decreased in Wilson's disease.
  • • A. Urea:
  • • C. Creatinine: Creatinine levels in urine are influenced by kidney function and muscle mass, and its excretion is not specifically decreased in Wilson's disease. Creatinine is commonly used as a marker for renal function rather than copper metabolism.
  • • C. Creatinine:
  • • D. Glucose: Glucose in urine, or glucosuria, typically indicates issues with renal glucose reabsorption or uncontrolled diabetes. It is not decreased in Wilson’s disease, as glucose excretion is not directly affected by copper accumulation.
  • • D. Glucose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson's disease is characterized by impaired copper excretion leading to its accumulation in various tissues, causing hepatic, neurological, and ocular manifestations. The disease affects protein metabolism, notably decreasing the urinary excretion of 3-methylhistidine. Understanding the metabolic disruptions in Wilson's disease is critical for diagnosing and managing this genetic condition effectively, highlighting the importance of recognizing specific biochemical markers associated with copper toxicity.

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications. They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death. Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons. It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.
  • • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers:
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa:
  • • Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.
  • • Option D. Labetalol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region

options.label: B
options.text: Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass

options.label: C
options.text: Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

options.label: D
options.text: Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed

questions.correct_answer: C. Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.
  • ➤ Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:
  • ➤ Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment Zone of resonance around the lump
  • ➤ Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  • ➤ Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  • ➤ Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and increased thirst. The patient's condition is indicative of a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. Which of the following conditions is not typically observed in this state?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glycogen storage is not typically observed in a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio because this state favors the breakdown of stored energy rather than its accumulation. Insulin is necessary for promoting the synthesis and storage of glycogen in the liver and muscle tissues. When insulin levels are low and glucagon is predominant, the body shifts towards mobilizing stored nutrients, resulting in increased glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen), gluconeogenesis (production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), and ketogenesis (production of ketone bodies from fatty acids). These processes provide energy to the body during fasting or insulin deficiency.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Glycogenolysis: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, which is stimulated by a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. This process helps maintain blood glucose levels during fasting or insulin deficiency.
  • • A. Glycogenolysis:
  • • B. Ketogenesis: Ketogenesis is the production of ketone bodies from fatty acids, commonly seen in low insulin states as the body shifts to alternative energy sources. This process is enhanced when insulin levels are insufficient to suppress lipolysis.
  • • B. Ketogenesis:
  • • C. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as amino acids and lactate. This process is activated in a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio, ensuring a continuous supply of glucose during periods of low carbohydrate intake or insulin deficiency.
  • • C. Gluconeogenesis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio, the body focuses on breaking down stored nutrients to provide energy, promoting glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and ketogenesis while inhibiting processes like glycogen storage, which requires high insulin levels. Understanding these metabolic shifts is crucial in managing conditions like diabetes, where insulin deficiency plays a significant role.

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to a genetic counseling clinic due to concerns about her family history of muscle weakness and exercise intolerance, she wants to know more about the potential genetic risks to her children. Which of the following statements is true regarding the mitochondrial genome?

options.label: A
options.text: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited equally from both parents.

options.label: B
options.text: Mitochondrial DNA has a low mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: Mitochondrial DNA is circular and primarily inherited from the mother.

options.label: D
options.text: All proteins required for mitochondrial function are encoded by mitochondrial DNA.

questions.correct_answer: C. Mitochondrial DNA is circular and primarily inherited from the mother.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular and maternally inherited, meaning it is passed down from the mother to her offspring. This inheritance pattern occurs because mitochondria are located in the cytoplasm of the egg, whereas sperm contributes minimal, if any, mitochondria to the zygote. The mtDNA contains 37 genes that encode 13 essential protein subunits of the electron transport chain, along with 2 ribosomal RNAs and 22 tRNAs. However, most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Mitochondrial DNA is inherited equally from both parents: This is incorrect as mitochondrial DNA is inherited almost exclusively from the mother due to the contribution of cytoplasmic content from the egg during fertilization, with paternal mitochondria being degraded.
  • • A. Mitochondrial DNA is inherited equally from both parents:
  • • B. Mitochondrial DNA has a low mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA: This statement is false; mtDNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, approximately 5-10 times higher, making it more susceptible to mutations due to its proximity to reactive oxygen species generated by the electron transport chain.
  • • B. Mitochondrial DNA has a low mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA:
  • • D. All proteins required for mitochondrial function are encoded by mitochondrial DNA: This is incorrect. Although mtDNA encodes some key proteins involved in the electron transport chain, most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and imported into the mitochondria.
  • • D. All proteins required for mitochondrial function are encoded by mitochondrial DNA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial DNA is maternally inherited, circular, and has a high mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. It encodes only a small number of proteins essential for mitochondrial function, while the majority of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA. Understanding the unique inheritance pattern and vulnerability of mtDNA helps in diagnosing mitochondrial disorders and managing the risks associated with these genetic conditions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. What will be the biopsy finding? (INICET NOV 2022) Thyroid transcription factor-1 P40 Napsin A Chromogranin

Ans. A) 1, 3

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following would you expect to find? (NEET PG 2021 )

options.label: A
options.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.correct_answer: A. Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO). It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • • It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Short stature : Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom. Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries). Shield-like chest : Broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Webbed neck : Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck. Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral. Cardiac defects : Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common. Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney. Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.
  • • Short stature : Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • • Short stature
  • • Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • • Primary amenorrhea
  • • Shield-like chest : Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • • Shield-like chest
  • • Webbed neck : Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • • Webbed neck
  • • Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • • Ptosis
  • • Cardiac defects : Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • • Cardiac defects
  • • Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • • Renal anomalies
  • • Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.
  • • Other features
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • streak ovaries
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD:
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture:
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: During a community health education session, an MBBS student is discussing the prevention of Typhoid Fever. Which of the following statements best captures the primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid in the community? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization

options.label: B
options.text: Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization

options.label: C
options.text: Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB

options.label: D
options.text: Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.correct_answer: B. Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, personal hygiene is more important than immunization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene. These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.
  • ➤ The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene.
  • ➤ These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.
